rev.comment: /* Online */ on second thought, this is a better link
Again, the UN and WHO uses FGC and FGM interchangeably. Neither term is "official". We can both prefere FGM, but representing the facts is our duty. Please read the references here and below.
/* Laws and outreach programs in countries where FGC is commonly practiced */
/* Sexual Consequences */ > "consequences" (per MoS); rm slanted sentence (strongly suggests that as "better information" will reveal "current views" to be wrong; the rest is unsourced); etc.
UN uses both terms, neither is "official". WHO is agency of UN, same thing, both terms used, neither is official. Accuracy is important, regardless of our personal views.
/* FGC: Geographical Practice */ Normalize image size
Added WHO to list of organizations who refer to FGC as FGM
/* TYPE I: Clitoridectomy */ capitalized "Islamic" as per [WP:MOSCAPS]
I think "Other practices of FGC "should be a subpage
Doing a major rewrite of this page as it contained some erroneous info about the types of FGC in existence and also trying to make it more succinct, easier to read and more relevant.
Undo revision 102335622 by [[Special:Contributions/209.244.7.253|209.244.7.253]] ([[User talk:209.244.7.253|talk]]), restoring removed references, aids, and text

/* Print */ we don't include book reviews.

/* Print */ Aldeeb, Sami (2000): Male and Female Circumcision in the Jewish, Christian and Muslim Communities, Religious debate. Beirut, ISBN 1 85513 406 3. (562 pages, a very comprehensive monography

rv. Again. Direct quotes must be direct or use ellipses to indicate gaps. See talk. (getting tired of this one.)
